Award.AwardTitle: Sketching and Self-Explanation for Diagram Comprehension in Math and Science: A Medium-Sized Empirical Research Proposal to REESE

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The PIs in this project from Temple University are examining the cognitive mechanisms that undergird two scaffolding strategies to improve student comprehension of diagrams. They are exploring the types of inferences that learners draw when they use self-explanation or sketching to explain visual representations in algebra and in biology. Working with middle school students, they are testing five comparisons of student performances on problems in those domains. They are examining the mechanisms underlying the success of these two interventions alone and in combination for mathematics and science problems to determine whether the two mechanisms are redundant or complementary. They are examining the nature of the inferences that are prompted by the two techniques and examining the differences in the ways that students with higher spatial ability use the strategies. They follow the performances of the students in a second year on other tasks using similar strategies to examine the how student sketching and self-explanation skills relate to long-term science and math learning.

Three groups of participants are completing individual computer-based sessions that include measures of spatial abilities, working memory, motivation for drawing and spatial tasks, and solving a series of math and science problems using sketching and/or self-explanation. Student performance on the problems are analyzed in terms of the pretest measures. One group of 200 students is being studied longitudinally in 6th through 8th grades to understand changes over time in the reasons why sketching and self-explanation are effective. A second group of 200 8th graders complete the measures in the first year of the project to provide a cross-sectional age comparison. A new group of 6th graders are being audiotaped while solving the problems in the 2nd year of the project in order to understand cognitive processes in finer-level detail. Analyses include cross-sectional t tests, regression models, longitudinal growth curve modeling, and analyses of verbal protocols from the audiotaped sessions. Research activities include developing low- and high spatial math and science problems and a coding scheme for the many different types of inferences. Three doctoral students are trained over the course of the project in school-based research, collection of verbal protocol data, coding, and data analysis. The team consists of experienced psychology researchers, with an expert advisory board providing an annual evaluation.

The products of the research are the low- and high-spatial problem sets, inference coding scheme, and scholarly papers reporting the results of the research. In addition to 600 participating students, the math and science teachers of those students are involved in summer work assisting with coding the student work. The project has an impact on teachers' use of self-explanation and/or sketching at many levels--from elementary through graduate education. The findings help point teachers towards when and with whom to use sketching and/or self-explanation, which leads to better learning in science and math.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Co-Principal Investigators: Julie L. Booth and Nora Newcombe (Temple University)

Purpose: This project compared drawing as a learning strategy by itself, self-explanation as a learning strategy by itself, and combinations of drawing and self-explanation, to a reading-only control group. The effectiveness of both drawing-to-learn and self-explanation has been attributed to their effects on inference and on metacognitive monitoring but these two approaches have rarely been compared. Participants were middle school students from science classes who solved science and mathematics problems. Individual differences (spatial, knowledge, and working memory) were tested as possible moderators of effects of drawing-to-learn on problem solving.

Project Activities: The research team conducted one large middle school study in 2012-2014, one small middle school study in 2019, and conducted a meta-analytic literature review of drawing-to-learn in 2018-2019. The team developed a set of science and mathematics problems for middle school students to solve, together with brief training videos to demonstrate thinking aloud, drawing-to-learn, and self-explanation. A sample of 199 middle school participants completed the science and mathematics problems, together with multiple individual difference measures. The team created a coding scheme for students? drawings, analyzed results, and has given multiple conference papers and submitted revised versions to multiple journals in sequence. For the meta-analysis, the team devised a search strategy, created a coding scheme, and wrote and revised a manuscript for publication. For the small-scale study, the team worked with a middle school to develop a curriculum-embedded set of activities involving drawing or summarizing, scored student responses, and compared effects on learning.

Pre-registration site: NA.

Publicly available data: NA.

WWC Review: NA.

Products: One peer-reviewed manuscript has been published from the project (https://doi.org/10.1007/s10956-019-09807-6).

Key Outcomes: The main findings from the studies are as follows:

  • With middle school students, drawing-to-learn, self-explanation, and summarization are equally useful for science and mathematics problem solving. Combination conditions were less effective than single conditions
  • The conditions did not differ in the extent to which they elicited inferences or monitoring
  • Participant drawings were more informative about student understanding than were participant verbalizations?teachers might pay more attention to what students draw than to what they say
  • A summary of the literature suggests that drawing-to-learn (versus no drawing) has a large average effect on middle school students? learning, but drawing-to-learn effects are significant for science but not mathematics in studies to date. The review shows that hand drawing is effective but drawing using computers does not show significant benefits

Structured Abstract

Setting: This project took place at middle schools in Pennsylvania, New Jersey, and Illinois.

Sample: Participants included middle school students recruited from science classes. These 226 students participated in 2 studies, one in the Philadelphia region and one in Central Illinois. The sample was 53% female and was racially diverse (59% White, 17% Black, 5% Asian, 9% Latino, and 10% multiple races). Participants were also socioeconomically diverse, with 21% from families where neither parent had earned a Bachelor?s degree

Experimental conditions: Experimental conditions included instructions to make a drawing as a problem-solving strategy (D2L), instructions to generate explanations for how to solve problems (self-explanation, combinations of these two, instructions to write a summary of the provided text, or a pretest-posttest only control condition.

Research Design and Methods: This project used a true experiment design, with random assignment of participants within classrooms. Participants completed pretest individual difference measures and demographics, then the non-control students solved science and math problems (science only in the small study). The large study was conducted individually in a separate room at the schools and included students thinking aloud. The small study was conducted in situ in classrooms using topics from the school?s curriculum, without a think-aloud procedure.

Key Measures: Key measures comprised the scoring of student answers for correctness as well as the depicted elements and relations among elements in drawings, coded student think-aloud and self-explanation transcripts. In addition, student working memory, spatial skills, and prior knowledge about the specific science and mathematics topics was measured.

Data Analytic Strategy: Researchers used linear mixed models (a form of multilevel modeling) to analyze effects of interventions while accounting for non-normality of the data, as well as observations and topics being nested within participants.

Project website: https://www.cromleylab.org/copy-of-gateway-bio-intervention
